all-or-nothing.name: All-or-Nothing Thinking
all-or-nothing.definition: Viewing situations in absolute, black-and-white terms without acknowledging middle ground.
challenge_tips: Practice using the words 'sometimes' and 'partially' instead of 'always' and 'never.'
List evidence of past successes to counteract extreme thoughts.
Journaling Prompt: What shades of gray can I see in this situation?
all-or-nothing.alternative: Getting a B shows I still learned a lot, even if it's not perfect. One grade doesn't define my worth.
self_reflection: How often do I think in extremes?
When was the last time I thought this way, and how did it affect my mood?
examples_and_contexts: At work: I missed one deadline; now my boss will think I’m unreliable.
In relationships: If they don’t respond right away, they must not care about me.
If I don't get an A on this test, I'm a complete failure.
If I miss one workout, my fitness goals are ruined.
If my presentation isn't perfect, my boss will think I'm incompetent.

overgeneralization.name: Overgeneralization
overgeneralization.definition: Drawing broad conclusions from a single event and applying them inappropriately to other situations.
challenge_tips: Challenge absolute words like 'always' and 'never.'
List examples of positive outcomes in similar situations.
Journaling Prompt: How might this situation be unique rather than a pattern?
overgeneralization.alternative: This date didn't work out, but I've had good connections before. Each person is different.
self_reflection: What evidence supports or contradicts my generalization?
How can I look for exceptions to this pattern in my life?
examples_and_contexts: At work: After one critique, you believe, 'I’ll always fail at this job.'
After one bad date: I'll never find someone who likes me.
Because my project was criticized, I'm bad at my job.
I forgot my friend's birthday; I'm a terrible friend.

catastrophizing.name: Catastrophizing
catastrophizing.definition: Assuming the worst possible outcome will happen and/or exaggerating the importance of negative events.
challenge_tips: Break down worst-case scenarios into manageable parts.
Practice mindfulness to stay grounded in the present moment.
Affirmation: 'Even if the worst happens, I can handle it.'
catastrophizing.alternative: Most people make minor mistakes in presentations. It's normal and unlikely to have serious consequences.
self_reflection: What evidence do I have for and against my worst-case scenario?
How likely is this outcome, realistically?
examples_and_contexts: If I make a mistake in this presentation, I'll definitely get fired.
If I fail this exam, my entire career is over.
If my friend doesn’t text back, they must hate me.

mental-filter.name: Mental Filter
mental-filter.definition: Focusing exclusively on negative aspects while filtering out all positive aspects of a situation.
challenge_tips: Deliberately list both positive and negative aspects of a situation.
Ask: What positive aspects am I ignoring?
Journaling Prompt: What’s the full story of this event, including the positives?
mental-filter.alternative: While there are areas for improvement, I also received praise for my creativity and teamwork.
self_reflection: What am I focusing on most right now?
What positive things might I be discounting in this situation?
examples_and_contexts: Only remembering the one criticism from a mostly positive work review.
Focusing on the one person who didn't like your presentation despite a majority giving positive feedback.
Thinking your day was awful because of a single mishap, ignoring everything that went well.

should-statements.name: Should Statements
should-statements.definition: Having rigid rules about how you and others 'should,' 'must,' or 'ought to' behave.
challenge_tips: Replace 'should' with 'would like' or 'prefer.'
Ask: Are these expectations realistic or fair?
Journaling Prompt: What flexibility can I allow myself in this situation?
should-statements.alternative: I would like to be productive, but it's okay and normal to have downtime.
self_reflection: What rigid 'should' rules am I applying to myself or others?
How can I make my expectations more compassionate and realistic?
examples_and_contexts: At work: I should always meet every deadline perfectly, or I’m a failure.
In relationships: My friends should always agree with me; otherwise, they don’t care about me.
I should always be productive.
People should always agree with me.
I must never make mistakes.

challenge_tips: Separate feelings from facts. Ask: What evidence supports or contradicts this thought?
Practice identifying neutral or positive interpretations of your emotions.
Journaling Prompt: What emotions am I feeling, and how might they influence my thoughts?
self_reflection: How often do I equate my feelings with facts?
What would a more balanced perspective look like in this situation?
emotional-reasoning.name: Emotional Reasoning
emotional-reasoning.definition: Believing something is true based on emotional response rather than evidence.
emotional-reasoning.alternative: Feeling stupid doesn’t make me stupid. Everyone feels this way sometimes, regardless of their abilities.
examples_and_contexts: In relationships: I feel unworthy of love, so no one must truly care about me.
I feel stupid, therefore I must be stupid.
I feel guilty, so I must have done something wrong.
I'm anxious about this decision, so it must be the wrong choice.

challenge_tips: Consider multiple factors that might have influenced the situation.
Ask: What other explanations might there be?
Journaling Prompt: What aspects of this situation are outside of my control?
self_reflection: How often do I take excessive responsibility for others' emotions or outcomes?
How can I remind myself of factors beyond my control?
personalization.name: Personalization
personalization.definition: Taking excessive responsibility for external events or blaming yourself inappropriately.
personalization.alternative: Many things could affect someone's mood that have nothing to do with me.
examples_and_contexts: At work: If the team doesn’t meet its goals, it’s my fault.
In relationships: My friend seemed upset, so I must have done something wrong.
My friend seems sad today; it must be something I did.
The project failed because I didn’t work hard enough, even though the whole team contributed.
If my child struggles in school, it’s because I’m a bad parent.

challenge_tips: Ask: What evidence do I have for this assumption?
Practice direct communication instead of guessing others’ thoughts.
Journaling Prompt: What alternative explanations can I think of for their behavior?
self_reflection: How often do I assume I know what others are thinking?
What would happen if I asked for clarification instead of assuming?
mind-reading.name: Mind Reading
mind-reading.definition: Assuming you know what others are thinking without evidence.
mind-reading.alternative: They might be busy, have their phone off, or be taking time to think of a response.
examples_and_contexts: They didn’t text back immediately; they must be mad at me.
They glanced at me in the meeting; they think I’m incompetent.
They canceled plans; they probably don’t like me anymore.

challenge_tips: Practice balanced evaluation by listing both positives and negatives of the situation.
Ask: What’s the actual impact of this mistake?
Journaling Prompt: How can I give my successes as much weight as my challenges?
self_reflection: How often do I blow mistakes out of proportion or downplay my achievements?
What would happen if I acknowledged my contributions more fairly?
magnification.name: Magnification/Minimization
magnification.definition: Exaggerating negative aspects while downplaying positive ones.
magnification.alternative: While I made a mistake, I also contributed many valuable ideas and hard work to this project.
examples_and_contexts: My mistake ruined the entire project (while ignoring all your contributions).
Nobody noticed the great ideas I shared because I stumbled over one word in my presentation.
I got one answer wrong, so I must be bad at this subject.

challenge_tips: Focus on specific behaviors rather than assigning a global label.
Ask: Is it fair to define someone (or myself) based on one incident?
Journaling Prompt: What evidence suggests this behavior is not the whole picture?
self_reflection: How often do I define myself or others by a single action or event?
What would happen if I saw behaviors as part of a larger pattern instead?
labeling-mislabeling.name: Labeling and Mislabeling
labeling-mislabeling.definition: Defining yourself or others based on a single incident or behavior.
labeling-mislabeling.alternative: I failed that test, but it doesn’t mean I’m a failure. I can work harder next time.
examples_and_contexts: I failed that test, so I’m a failure.
They forgot my birthday, so they’re a bad friend.

challenge_tips: Acknowledge positive feedback and achievements without dismissing them.
Ask: What evidence do I have that their praise was genuine?
Journaling Prompt: How can I learn to trust positive feedback?
self_reflection: How often do I dismiss positive feedback or experiences?
What would happen if I accepted praise at face value?
disqualifying-positive.name: Disqualifying the Positive
disqualifying-positive.definition: Rejecting positive experiences by insisting they don’t count for some reason.
disqualifying-positive.alternative: Their feedback was genuine, and my promotion reflects my hard work.
examples_and_contexts: At work: They said I did a great job, but they were just being nice.
In relationships: They complimented me, but they didn’t mean it.
They said I did well, but they were just being nice.
I got promoted, but it’s just because no one else applied.

blaming.name: Blaming
blaming.definition: Holding others responsible for your problems or blaming yourself for things outside your control.
challenge_tips: Recognize the factors within your control and focus on those.
Avoid assuming total responsibility for things outside your influence.
Ask: How can I respond to this situation constructively?
blaming.alternative: I can’t control others’ actions, but I can work on my response to this situation.
self_reflection: How often do I notice this thought pattern?
What evidence supports or contradicts this thought?
How can I approach this situation differently?
examples_and_contexts: At work: Example of how Blaming might manifest at work.
In relationships: Example of how Blaming might manifest in relationships.
I’m unhappy because my partner doesn’t do what I want.
If only I had been more careful, this wouldn’t have happened.

control-fallacies.name: Control Fallacies
control-fallacies.definition: Believing you are either entirely responsible for everything or powerless over your circumstances.
challenge_tips: Separate what you can control from what you can’t.
Ask: What small steps can I take to improve the situation?
Focus on actions within your power rather than external factors.
control-fallacies.alternative: I can’t control everything, but I can influence the outcome by trying.
self_reflection: How often do I notice this thought pattern?
What evidence supports or contradicts this thought?
How can I approach this situation differently?
examples_and_contexts: At work: Example of how Control Fallacies might manifest at work.
In relationships: Example of how Control Fallacies might manifest in relationships.
If I had been a better parent, my child wouldn’t have struggled.
There’s no point in trying; nothing I do will change anything.

fairness-fallacy.name: Fallacy of Fairness
fairness-fallacy.definition: Believing life should always be fair and feeling upset when it isn’t.
challenge_tips: Acknowledge that fairness is subjective and not always achievable.
Ask: How can I adapt to this situation instead of focusing on fairness?
Focus on what you can learn or do to move forward.
fairness-fallacy.alternative: Life isn’t always fair, but I can choose how to respond to unfair situations.
self_reflection: How often do I notice this thought pattern?
What evidence supports or contradicts this thought?
How can I approach this situation differently?
examples_and_contexts: At work: Example of how Fallacy of Fairness might manifest at work.
In relationships: Example of how Fallacy of Fairness might manifest in relationships.
It’s not fair that they got the job when I worked harder.
I shouldn’t have to deal with this; it’s not fair.

heavens-reward.name: Heaven’s Reward Fallacy
heavens-reward.definition: Expecting that sacrifices or hard work should always be rewarded and feeling bitter when they aren’t.
challenge_tips: Reflect on intrinsic motivations rather than external rewards.
Ask: What have I gained or learned from this experience?
Focus on personal growth and satisfaction instead of external validation.
heavens-reward.alternative: Hard work doesn’t always guarantee recognition, but I’ve grown and learned through the process.
self_reflection: How often do I notice this thought pattern?
What evidence supports or contradicts this thought?
How can I approach this situation differently?
examples_and_contexts: At work: Example of how Heaven’s Reward Fallacy might manifest at work.
In relationships: Example of how Heaven’s Reward Fallacy might manifest in relationships.
After all I’ve done, I deserve recognition.
I worked so hard, but it feels like it was for nothing.

challenge_tips: Ask yourself: How can I know for certain this will happen?
Focus on the possibilities rather than fixating on negative outcomes.
Journaling Prompt: What small steps can I take to challenge this assumption?
self_reflection: When was the last time I assumed a negative outcome? Was I right?
What would happen if I allowed myself to explore the possibility of a positive result?
fortune-telling.name: Fortune Telling
fortune-telling.definition: Making negative predictions about the future without supporting evidence.
fortune-telling.alternative: While I might not get the job, applying gives me a chance and good interview practice.
examples_and_contexts: There’s no point in applying for that job because they won’t hire me.
No one will talk to me at the party, so I shouldn’t go.
